Maryland's potentially powerful
lacrosse team proved itself more
of an enigma than ever last Saturday when its best efforts against
Navy availed it but a 6-6 deadlock
after two extra periods.
Corning as it did on the heels of
their stunning 8-3 defeat at the
hands of St. John's, this setback
relegated the College Parkers to the
cellar position of Maryland's Big
Four.
Coach Jack Faber's ten seemed
headed for a certain triumph at the
end of the first half, having amassed
a 4-1 lead at that juncture. But the
Tars came back strong to knot the
count at 5-all and then hold their_
own in the overtime periods.

Expected Tomorrow
A real treat is in store tomorrow
for those track fans who like to
watch specialists in action. Out at
llomewood Field, where Hopkins
and Maryland will match strides,
Jumps, and tosses, the aforementioned specialists will be plentiful.
Maryland will offer Earl Widtnyer, one of the speediest dash men

Evans, 440 ace, who recently stepped the distance in 49.4 seconds:
and Bob Slye, whose performances
in taking the hurdles have been little
Short of sensational.
In rebuttal, Hopkins can point
Paul Holtzman, in the two-mile;
Jack King, in the middle distances:
kue Merson, Johnny Weeks, Will
Neu, Joe Moravek, Paul Coburn,
and Opie Chancellor.

Maryland's potentially powerful
lacrosse team proved itself more
of an enigma than ever last Saturday when its best efforts against
Navy availed it but a 6-6 deadlock
after two extra periods.
Corning as it did on the heels of
their stunning 8-3 defeat at the
hands of St. John's, this setback
relegated the College Parkers to the
cellar position of Maryland's Big
Four.
Coach Jack Faber's ten seemed
headed for a certain triumph at the
end of the first half, having amassed
a 4-1 lead at that juncture. But the
Tars came back strong to knot the
count at 5-all and then hold their_
own in the overtime periods.

Battle Of Experts
Expected Tomorrow
A real treat is in store tomorrow
for those track fans who like to
watch specialists in action. Out at
llomewood Field, where Hopkins
and Maryland will match strides,
Jumps, and tosses, the aforementioned specialists will be plentiful.
Maryland will offer Earl Widtnyer, one of the speediest dash men
In the entire country; Warren
Evans, 440 ace, who recently stepped the distance in 49.4 seconds:
and Bob Slye, whose performances
in taking the hurdles have been little
Short of sensational.
In rebuttal, Hopkins can point
Paul Holtzman, in the two-mile;
Jack King, in the middle distances:
kue Merson, Johnny Weeks, Will
Neu, Joe Moravek, Paul Coburn,
and Opie Chancellor.

Of Matches By 7-2
Trim Haverford And Swarthmore
By Identical Margin In
Successful Weekend
Haverford and Swarthmore
Colleges both went down to defeat at the hands of the Black and
Blue racqueters by the score of
7-2 last weekend.
The Haverford netmen were
defeated at Haverford on Friday
while Swarthmore was beaten the
following day at Homewood.
Two More Matches

Only two matches remain to be
played on the Blue jay tennis
schedule. Today Washington and
Jefferson will swap strokes with
Hopkins here at Hottewood and
on Friday the Jays meet Lehigh
University on the home courts.
Against Swarthmore •the best
performances were turned in by
Palitz and Ladensky in the singles and Siverd and Kramer in
the doubles.
Palitz defeated W y the in
straight se-ts, 6-2, 6-2, while Ladensky won from Hutson, '6-4,
6-1. Kramer and Siverd trounced
Hood and Turner of Swarthmore,
6-2, 6-4, displaying fine form.

succeed Opie Chancellor as captain of the Rifle team for next
year. C. U. Wolf was chosen
president of the Rifle club and
Phillip Guild will act as manager
of the Rifle team.

(Continued from Page 1, Col. 1)
the evening of June ninth in the
grand ball room of the Alcazar
and will feature Jan Garber and

Two other musical organizations are to be heard during June
Week. Jimmy DeAngelis will provide the music for the Junior
Prom at the Alcazar on June
seventh, while the Ramblers will
be heard on the following evening
at the Annapolis Roads Club
where the annual regatta is to be
held.
It was also announced that
tickets for June Week are now on
sale and may be secured from any
member of the committee. The
price of the entire Week's events
is $7.70. The Senior Ball is $3.85.
Prices for individual events and
for the whole Week will be substantially increased on and after
May 28.
